newsitem.title: LEBANON: CNN reopens Beirut bureau after 12-year closure.
newsitem.headline: CNN reopens Beirut bureau after 12-year closure.

text.p: The U.S. television news network CNN said on Tuesday it was returning to Beirut after a 12-year absence forced by Lebanon's 1975-1990 civil war.

CNN closed its bureau in 1985 after the kidnapping of its bureau chief Jerry Levin, who was later released. It said its bureau would be staffed by non-Americans, headed by British journalist Brent Sadler.
The United States continues to ban its citizens from going to Lebanon. The ban was imposed in 1985 after Moslem militants hijacked a TWA airliner and killed a U.S. passenger.
Lebanon, which is seeking to have the U.S. ban lifted, welcomed the CNN decision.
Beirut earned the reputation of the world's most dangerous city for foreigners in the late 1980s because of kidnappings by Moslem fundamentalists.
